description: From Anglo-Norman descaunt, from Medieval Latin discantus.

entries.meaning: A lengthy discourse on a subject.
examples: Upon that simplest of themes how magnificent a descant!

entries.meaning: (music) A counterpoint melody sung or played above the theme.

verbs.description: descant (third-person singular simple present descants, present participle descanting, simple past and past participle descanted)

examples: Involving some interesting, intellectual trips, she was descanting lightly to right and left.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, music) To sing or play a descant.
